data.text:
The only other “And Philosophy” essay of mine that mentions the Church is inÂ Sherlock Holmes and Philosophy,Â though I don’t discuss the obvious thing: the second half of “A Study in Scarlet” where evil Mormons use Danites to terrorize women in marriages with lecherous older men (incidentally, when a young’un, I read a version of “A Study in Scarlet” that cut out the “Mormon” bits as unnecessary, and – at the time – I didn’t even notice they were missing; it wasn’t until much later in life I found out about the evil Mormon/Danite section).

Rather, I mentioned (in passing) our Church as a group with a (theoretically) open canon of scripture, whereas Sherlock Holmes has a (basically) closed canon.

Of course, even when a canon is âclosedâ that doesnât mean itâs totally determined; there are always those pesky soft edges.Â What to do with the two Doyle stories that appear in French editions of âThe Complete Worksâ but are omitted from English editions because itâs not clear the âwell known investigatorâ mentioned (but otherwise nameless) in both tales is Sherlock?

Or what about the several stories about Sherlock such as âHow Watson Learned the Trick” – written by and published during Doyleâs lifetime yet were never admitted to the âcanonâ (to say nothing of the stories written by his son, which were intended to serve as new canon but were never accepted by the readers).

Of course, things âoutsideâ the canon influence our perceptions of canon.Â Holmes likely rarely wore a deerstalker cap, but actor William Gillette portrayed Holmes with one, so thatâs how we picture him now.

However, think of our tradition.Â While we revere Joseph Smith, not everything he wrote or said is âcanonized.âÂ Some sections of the D&C are smaller sections of longer letters or discourses.Â So, like how not all of Doyleâs Sherlock writings are considered âcanonâ, we have a similar issue, where not all writing attributed to an authoritative prophet are canon either.

While one might say the big difference is that in Holmesian canon, the readers/fans/experts determine canon, whereas in our Church the leadership does.Â But the lines there are, of course, not so clearly defined.Â Many things became canon due to popularity, so that the leadership merely reflected popular will. On the other hand, there are times when leadership imposed canon on something, but it took a while to âtakeâ (so to speak) or not take amongst the laity.Â And these dynamics play out whether weâre talking about the LDS tradition, Sherlock Holmes, or even Star Wars (after Disney bought it, Disney declared everything up to that point except the movies non-canon â but some things from the old canon were so popular theyâve found their way back in despite that).

And, to bring it back to the LDS connection and Holmes, the most fascinating of Holmesian âapocryphalâ texts is when Doyle, before Holmes proved popular, wrote a play in three acts called âAngel of Darknessâ â starring Doctor Watson battling evil Mormon Danites in America and finding love along the way.Â While some Holmesian experts have tried to save the latter half of âA Study in Scarletâ (as it is clearly wildly exaggerated at best and outright false at worst) as either âtrue in the Holmes universeâ or âthe murderâs self-serving lies as told to Watson who wouldnât know any betterâ, no one tries to figure out how this play might fit into the canon.Â Like the Infancy Gospel of Thomas, itâs just too wildly contradictory to the rest of the accepted canon to work.

Draw whatever lessons from all that you want to.
